Description: Robert Bosch GmbH, the world's largest independent parts supplier to the automotive industry, based in Gerlingen, Germany, has agreed to plead guilty and to pay a $57.8 million criminal fine for its role in a conspiracy to fix prices and rig bids for spark plugs, oxygen sensors and starter motors sold to automobile and internal combustion engine manufacturers in the United States and elsewhere.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/robert-bosch-gmbh-agrees-plead-guilty-price-fixing-and-bid-rigging-automobile-parts-installed

Description: Fiat Chrysler and Robert Bosch agreed to pay a total of more than $170 million to settle multistate litigation alleging they illegally altered measurements of vehicle emissions when Fiat installed Bosch electronics designed to evade diesel emission tests. Robert Bosch's share was $98.7 million.
Info Source: http://illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2019_01/20190110b.html

Description: Resolution of allegations that the company produced emissions defeat devices that were installed in Ram 1500 pick-up trucks and Jeep Grand Cherokee SUVs sold in Alaska.
Info Source: http://www.law.state.ak.us/press/releases/2020/010820-ChryslerBosch.html

Description: Bosch agreed to pay $550,000 in settlement of allegations it produced devices to cheat emissions tests for Volkswagen, Porche and Audi. WV did not participate in the multistate settlement over the emissions cheating allegations.
Info Source: https://mailchi.mp/wvago/wva-ag-secures-additional-550k-in-emissions-cheating-scandal-708190

Description: Bosch agreed to pay $327.5 million to customers and dealers to resolve allegations that it helped produce the defeat device involved in the Volkswagen emissions cheating scandal.
Private Litigation Case Title: IN RE: Volkswagen "Clean Diesel" Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/922946/vw-3-liter-deal-approved-as-cheat-tab-hits-record-17-5b

Description: Robert Bosch agreed to an settlement worth an estimated $63.3 million to resolve class action litigation concerning the sale of Mercedes-Benz vehicles with emissions-cheating software. Mercedes-Benz agreed to pay an estimated $700 million (see separate entry).
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1257515
